results.title: The Maids
results.creator_credit: Christopher Miles, Robert Enders, Cinevision Ltee and Ely Landau Organization
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Adapted from French playwright, Jean Genet’s absurdist play, “The Maids” is about a pair of sisters caught up in a twisted play-acting game whereby their antipathy for their mistress and for each other, is revealed. After having her husband framed and imprisoned, the sisters, employed as maids for Madame, plan to poison her. In her temporary absence however they fantasise about dominance, wealth and power with Claire (Susannah York) acting as Madame, whilst Solange (Glenda Jackson) alternately fawns over then rants mercilessly, spitting out endless bile that speaks of her own self-loathing and hatred for her class. The film presents an impressive, and appropriate, sense of claustrophobia as the two women steer along a tragic course. Stellar cast also includes Vivien Merchant.

results.title: Crooked Mick of the Speewah
results.creator_credit: Philip Smith, Luke Eve and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Strong-Arm Sam and his promoter Gus are down on their luck. Sick and tired of hearing about how much stronger Crooked Mick of the Speewah is, they decide to travel to the Speewah and challenge him.
Cast includes Bruce Spence. Based on a short story by Pat Edwards.

results.title: Boys Grammar
results.creator_credit: Rozlyn Clayton-Vincent, Justin Davies, Dean Francis and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Set in an exclusive boys school, Gareth learns that his feelings can be validated and expressed only through violence.
A graphic and disturbing look at the ritual of hazing.

results.title: Black berries
results.creator_credit: Ema Mulholland, Rosie Travers and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Black Berries is a story about Candy and Lao, two 12 year old best friends. One fateful day while walking home, the girls come to a laneway - the short cut. Lao begins to walk down it but, in a moment of loyalty, Candy keeps a promise she made to her mother and chooses the long way home.
Cast includes Anne Louise Lambert.

results.title: Edward Albee's A Delicate Balance
results.creator_credit: Edward Albee, Tony Richardson, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Listening carefully to the sharp and witty dialogue is the key to engaging with this dramatic play adapted for the screen. Produced originally on the New York stage by Richard Barr and Clinton Wilder, adapted here for the screen by the playwright Edward Albee. Set in suburban New England, a well-to-do older couple (Katharine Hepburn and Paul Scofield) live their lives in a staid familiarity that can only set in with a long-term relationship. The delicate balance that is their marriage is rocked only by the presence of the wife’s alcoholic sister Claire (Kate Reid) and their melancholic daughter (Lee Remick) dealing with yet another failed marriage. Two friends (Joseph Cotton and Betsy Blair) turn up wanting to stay for good but as a group they work through this to get back the ‘balance’. A Pulitzer Prize winning play, this screen version deals with the notions of family, friendship and love, directed by Tony Richardson.

results.title: Afterlife
results.creator_credit: Rozlyn Clayton-Vincent, Justin Davies, Dean Francis and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
A female flight attendant on a trans-pacific flight asks the question, “What would you do with the last five minutes of your life?” And sees it answered in the worst-case scenario.
Cast includes Lisa Hensley.

results.title: In celebration
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Anderson, Ely Landau and Almo
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Atmospheric adaptation of David Storey’s emotionally charged play, about three sons who return to their Yorkshire mining town for their parent’s wedding anniversary - an event that stirs up suppressed resentment, childhood memories and bitterness, despite the men’s successful lives. Impressive performances from Alan Bates, James Bolam and Brian Cox who reprise their stage roles as the three middle class sons. Part of the American Film Theatre Collection.

results.title: Simon Gray's Butley = Butley
results.creator_credit: Harold Pinter, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Simon Gray’s screen adaptation of his play “Butley” which was originally produced on the West End Stage by Michael Codron and directed by Harold Pinter. Alan Bates (who won a Tony Award for this role on the stage) is outstanding as Butley, a university lecturer whose life is falling apart. This day-in-the-life drama, set in his work place (a small college office) gradually unfolds as his life unravels. Butley’s sharp verbal wit is relentless as is his need for a smoke and stiff drink - especially as his wife (Susan Engel) has left him for another man. His workmate and previous flatmate Joey (Richard O’Callaghan) is leaving him too to be with his boyfriend Reg (Michael Byrne). Confoundedly confrontational as he feels everyone is deserting him, Butley could be disliked by the viewer but there is a subtly to Bates’ performance that somehow makes him likeable beyond the verbal gymnastics and dishevelled exterior. Cast includes Jessica Tandy, Georgina Hale, Simon Rouse.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harold Pinter, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films

Alan Bates (who won a Tony Award for this role on the stage) is outstanding as Butley, a university lecturer whose life is falling apart. This day-in-the-life drama, set in his work place (a small college office) gradually unfolds as his life unravels. Butley’s sharp verbal wit is relentless as is his need for a smoke and stiff drink - especially as his wife (Susan Engel) has left him for another man. His workmate and previous flatmate Joey (Richard O’Callaghan) is leaving him too to be with his boyfriend Reg (Michael Byrne). Confoundedly confrontational as he feels everyone is deserting him, Butley could be disliked by the viewer but there is a subtly to Bates’ performance that somehow makes him likeable beyond the verbal gymnastics and dishevelled exterior. Cast includes Jessica Tandy, Georgina Hale, Simon Rouse.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Simon Gray’s screen adaptation of his play “Butley” which was originally produced on the West End Stage by Michael Codron and directed by Harold Pinter. Alan Bates (who won a Tony Award for this role on the stage) is outstanding as Butley, a university lecturer whose life is falling apart. This day-in-the-life drama, set in his work place (a small college office) gradually unfolds as his life unravels. Butley’s sharp verbal wit is relentless as is his need for a smoke and stiff drink - especially as his wife (Susan Engel) has left him for another man. His workmate and previous flatmate Joey (Richard O’Callaghan) is leaving him too to be with his boyfriend Reg (Michael Byrne). Confoundedly confrontational as he feels everyone is deserting him, Butley could be disliked by the viewer but there is a subtly to Bates’ performance that somehow makes him likeable beyond the verbal gymnastics and dishevelled exterior. Cast includes Jessica Tandy, Georgina Hale, Simon Rouse.

results.title: The Homecoming
results.creator_credit: Peter Hall, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Lauded and much admired adaptation of the caustic Harold Pinter play about three estranged brothers and their father. When one son - an accomplished university professor - visits from America with his wife, the family are reunited in their London home only to find that tension and malevolence simmers dangerously below their every interaction. As a study of male violence, family dysfunction, rage and suppressed emotion, Pinter’s screenplay shines even if the characters’ motivations are opaque, and their capacity for hatred, disturbing. Cast includes: Vivien Merchant, Terence Rigby, Paul Rogers, Cyril Cusack, Michael Jayston, and Ian Holm who is brilliant as the menacing pimp, Lenny.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Hall, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
